imaging_tests.findings: Normal left ventricular function, no valvular abnormalities.
Mild right temporal atrophy, no acute pathology.

visits.notes: Mr. Smith was referred to neurology after a history of seizures that started approximately 20 years ago. He was diagnosed with temporal lobe epilepsy at that time. Initially, his seizures were well-controlled with carbamazepine, and there were no issues for 15 years. However, over the past year, the frequency of his seizures has increased, prompting a referral for further assessment and management.
visits.plan: Continue carbamazepine for now. Consider further follow-up if seizures become more frequent or severe.

visits.notes: Mr. Smith presented with an increase in seizure frequency over the past 12 months. Carbamazepine, which he had been taking for 11 years, was no longer sufficient in controlling his seizures. Consequently, the decision was made to switch to sodium valproate. Unfortunately, Mr. Smith developed nausea with sodium valproate, leading to a further change in medication.
visits.plan: Discontinue sodium valproate. Start Levetiracetam and monitor for side effects. Follow-up in 3 months.

visits.notes: After switching to Levetiracetam, Mr. Smith experienced side effects, including irritability and mood disturbances. As a result, we transitioned to Lamotrigine. Following this adjustment, Mr. Smith reported no further seizures. His neurological examination was unremarkable, and he is now adhering to the treatment regimen without difficulty. This medication has significantly improved his seizure control.
visits.plan: Continue Lamotrigine 50mg BD. Follow-up in 6 months. No further changes to medication at this time.

visits.notes: Mr. Smith presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of a severe headache and dizziness. He described the headache as a dull, constant pain, which had lasted for several hours. No new neurological symptoms such as seizures or altered consciousness were reported. The clinical examination showed no focal neurological deficits. Mr. Smith's medical history includes a history of temporal lobe epilepsy, for which he has been stable with Lamotrigine. There were no signs of acute exacerbation of his epilepsy. After appropriate investigations, it was concluded that his symptoms were likely related to a non-neurological cause, such as a vestibular issue or tension headache.
visits.plan: Advise Mr. Smith to follow up with his GP for further evaluation of possible non-neurological causes of the headache. No changes to his epilepsy management are necessary at this time.
